page.title: 14Local History-Ide Hill
page.content: Ide Hill and the surrounding area lies at the southern end of the ancient parish of Sundridge.It sits on the sandstone ridge that separates the fertile Holmesdale valley from the stiff clays of the Weald. In Saxon and early Norman times herds of pigs would be taken into the woods in the autumn to feed on the harvest of acorns. The original spelling in an ancient deed is Sudrish and in the original Domesday survey Sondresse. The manor of Sundridge belonged to the Archbishops of Canterbury for over 700 years until the Reformation and was leased out by them to various wealthy families. See Hasted volume 3 for details of the descent of the manor.
